name: Demoiselle Crane
description: It is gray, with only the head and front of the neck black. At the junction of the neck and chest, it has longer, drooping black feathers forming a collar-like appearance, along with white 'ear tufts' from elongated feathers behind the eyes. It is the smallest of all cranes and, unlike most other species, is abundant in the wild with no threat of extinction. It nests in dry areas, laying its eggs directly on the ground.
spread_note: Central Asia from the Black Sea to NE China, winters in South Asia and North Africa
food_note: Plant seeds, mollusks, worms, insects, and small vertebrates
proportions: Length 85–95 cm; wingspan 150–170 cm; weight 2–3 kg
attractions: It is the smallest of all cranes and, unlike most other species, is abundant in the wild with no threat of extinction. It nests in dry areas, laying its eggs directly on the ground. It is migratory and hunted by sport shooters during migration.
breeding: As early as 1933, Mrs. Ludmila Jandová, wife of the zoo’s founder, donated four demoiselle cranes, one of which lived here until 1948. More cranes arrived in 1974, and since then, this species has been kept at Prague Zoo. The first successful breeding of two chicks occurred in 1993.
